meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! It's your old pal, back with another groovy review of Crime Boss: Rockay City. I'm not saying I'm a hot shot critic or anything (although, let's be real, I do have some seriously sharp reviewing skills). But hey, someone's gotta give it to you straight, and that someone is me!

Now, about this game... Where do I even start? Well, let's just say it's an ambitious attempt at creating a crime caper like no other. And by "ambitious," I mean it tries really, really hard – but ultimately ends up feeling like a soggy mess.

I mean, come on, IGN! You're saying this game is like an "air ball" on all fronts? Yeah, I get that. The gameplay can be pretty wonky at times. But hey, what's wrong with a little sloppy play here and there? It's not like we're talking about a super serious, high-stakes crime drama here (although, let's be real, the voice acting could use some work). I mean, if you're gonna be bad, just own it like they do in those 90s movies!

Game Informer says this game is proof that even with A-list celebs, a game can still tank. And honestly, yeah... The cast does seem to phone it in at times (I mean, who doesn't love some good ol' Danny Trejo or Michael Madsen though?).

SpazioGames gives it some props for being "fun" and having some solid design ideas, but even they admit the game feels "not-so-polished." I mean, it's like they took all these awesome concepts and then just... forgot to make the game actually good.

GamingTrend says it has some depth, but it's overshadowed by what could have been. Yeah, that about sums it up for me. It's like they had this amazing crime caper on paper, but then decided to make a watered-down, unengaging game instead.

Hardcore Gamer gives it a thumbs-up for fans of rogue-like games and 90s crime flicks (which, let's be real, is a super specific niche). But honestly? If you're expecting Payday or GTA levels of awesomeness, you're gonna be disappointed.

Metro GameCentral says this game is an "unlikeable" clone of Payday that wastes its celebrity cast. Ouch! That hurts, right?

CD-Action gives it a solid middle-of-the-road score, saying it's just... meh. Yeah, that about sums it up for me too – it's not terrible, but it's not great either.

So there you have it, folks – my take on Crime Boss: Rockay City. It's like they took all these awesome ideas and then decided to phone it in instead (see what I did there?). If you're looking for some real crime caper action, keep looking (or wait for a sale...).
